articles.headline: Japanese Rush to Buy Before Rise in Sales Tax
articles.snippet: The first sales tax jump since 1997 has Japan’s businesses, politicians and consumers worried.
articles.abstract: The first sales tax jump since 1997 has Japan’s businesses, politicians and consumers worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — March was a boom month for Askul, but the online retailer is far from happy. Shoppers racing to beat an impending increase in Japan’s national sales tax swamped Askul’s systems, snapping up toilet paper, instant rice and other essentials that will be more expensive when the rate goes up to 8 percent on Tuesday, from 5 percent.

articles.headline: Cobalts Were Seen as Lemons From Start, State Data Shows
articles.snippet: Owners of the Chevrolet car complained about power steering failures, locks opening and closing and doors jamming shut long before the car became known for having a deadly ignition defect.
articles.abstract: Owners of the Chevrolet car complained about power steering failures, locks opening and closing and doors jamming shut long before the car became known for having a deadly ignition defect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before the Chevrolet Cobalt became known for having a deadly ignition defect, it was already seen as a lemon. Owners complained about power steering failures, locks inexplicably opening and closing, doors jamming shut in the rain — even windows falling out.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Fault Runs Deep in Ultrafast Trading
articles.snippet: A new book points out problems with high-frequency trading, but the fault lies with the markets themselves.
articles.abstract: A new book points out problems with high-frequency trading, but the fault lies with the markets themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The United States stock market, the most iconic market in global capitalism, is rigged.”

articles.headline: Scrutiny for Wall Street’s Warp Speed
articles.snippet: Critics argue that Michael Lewis’s new book on high-speed trading broke no new ground. But few wanted to miss out on the conversation.
articles.abstract: Critics argue that Michael Lewis’s new book on high-speed trading broke no new ground. But few wanted to miss out on the conversation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street traders are used to waking up before dawn. But on Monday, they didn’t rush to read the overnight news from Asia — it was the latest from Michael Lewis.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and William Alden

articles.headline: Abbas Takes Defiant Step, and Mideast Talks Falter
articles.snippet: An effort by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority to join 15 international agencies threatened to derail the fraught peace talks.
articles.abstract: An effort by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority to join 15 international agencies threatened to derail the fraught peace talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Middle East peace talks verged on a breakdown Tuesday night, after President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority defied the United States and Israel by taking concrete steps to join 15 international agencies — a move to gain the benefits of statehood outside the negotiations process.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren, Michael R. Gordon and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Corporate Lobbyists Assail Tax Overhaul They Once Cheered
articles.snippet: The undisputed winners of a legislative battle over the nation’s tax code are the lobbying shops, which often work to simply preserve the status quo.
articles.abstract: The undisputed winners of a legislative battle over the nation’s tax code are the lobbying shops, which often work to simply preserve the status quo.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just two days after he proposed a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s tax code, Representative Dave Camp, Republican of Michigan, traveled to Park City, Utah, for a glittering fund-raiser attended by lobbyists from some of the nation’s largest corporations, all with enormous stakes in the tax battle to come.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Jonathan Weisman
